snippet: With Russia in control of Crimea, worries mounted in Kiev that the mostly ethnic-Russian east could be next to fall.
abstract: Ukraine's interim government moves to head off violence threatening to set off Russian invasion of its eastern provinces, recruiting wealthy businessmen to become provincial governors there in effort to dampen secessionist sentiment; Russia's control of Crimean Peninsula has raised fears that ethnic-Russian east could be next to fall.

byline.contributor: Reporting was contributed by Andrew Roth from Kharkiv, Ukraine; Andrew Kramer from Kiev; Alison Smale, David M. Herszenhorn, Noah Sneider and Patrick Reevell from Simferopol, Ukraine; Andrew Higgins from Sevastopol; Stephen Castle from Brussels; and Somini Sengupta from the United Nations.

lead_paragraph: With Russia in control of Crimea, worries mounted in Kiev that the mostly ethnic-Russian east could be next to fall.

headline.main: Ukrainian Government Rushes to Dampen Secessionist Sentiment
headline.print_headline: Ukrainian Government Rushes to Dampen Secessionist Sentiment
